reflective of the cost of regulation secs 22220  reserved article ii  city council division 1  generally mayor the mayor shall have the general superintendence of the affairs of the city  shall preside at all meetings of the city council and it shall be the mayors duty to see that all laws ordinances resolutions and rules of the city council are observed and enforced and that all officers of the city shall faithfully discharge the duties required of them    mayor pro tem election the city council shall elect from its body a mayor pro tem who shall during the illness absence or disqualification of the mayor act in the mayors stead and be clothed with all rights privileges and duties of the mayor    secs 223247  reserved division 2  rules of order and procedure meetings when held the city council shall meet regularly at least once each month at such place and time as it may fix and prescribe special meetings may be called by the mayor at any time for the consideration and determination of any questions or matters requiring immediate attention of which special meeting the city clerk shall give the members notice    speaking at meetings  decorum at meetings  notices to city council from members of the public  disturbing or interrupting meetings  violations a monthly public meetings of city council and city council committees unless otherwise provided by a majority vote of the city council the mayor and city council shall meet at least two times each calendar month the first meeting shall be an agenda setting meeting and the second meeting shall be the regular monthly meeting such meetings shall be at such times and dates as established by the city council from time to time nothing in this subsection shall be construed to prohibit called meetings otherwise allowed by law  nor shall any provision of this subsection be construed to require that both meetings be held each calendar month if a majority of the city council agrees to dispense with one of such meetings  provided however that unless prevented by circumstances or events beyond the control of the mayor and city council the mayor and city council shall have at least a regular monthly meeting each calendar month all meetings of the mayor and city council shall be held and conducted under the provisions of the georgia open meetings act b meeting agenda at least 48 hours prior to each meeting of the mayor and city council or any committee thereof the city clerk or the designee thereof shall publish an agenda of the matters anticipated to be considered or discussed at the meeting the fact that a particular matter is not included on the published agenda shall not prevent the matter from being considered provided that a majority of the city council or the council committee as the case may be adopts a motion approving the addition of the matter to the agenda at any time during the meeting c public hearings at each meeting of the mayor and city council or any committee thereof when the mayor and city council or a committee of the city council is conducting a public hearing in accord with the requirements of federal state or local laws regulations or ordinances any person desiring to address the mayor and city council or a committee of city council during such public hearing regarding the subject matter of the public hearing shall be authorized to do so such person must be recognized by the presiding officer prior to speaking at the public hearing comments by persons speaking during the public hearing shall be directed to the presiding officer and not to individual members of the city council and unless otherwise provided by state law or local ordinance the comments of such person addressing a public hearing shall be limited to five minutes per person any person speaking during a public hearing shall limit his or her comments to the subject matter of the public hearing and any statements or comments made by such person not related to the subject matter of the public hearing shall be immediately ruled out of order by the presiding officer at the conclusion of the time to speak at such public hearing each speaker shall terminate his or her remarks d agenda items at any regular monthly meeting of the city council members of the public desiring to address the mayor and city council regarding items that appear on the published city council agenda shall personally sign up to do so at the meeting location on the day of the meeting as long as such person signs up to speak prior to the time that the meeting is called to order by the presiding officer a person signing up to speak on an agenda item must indicate the item on which such person desires to address the mayor and city council by reference to the meeting agenda at the time such person signs up to speak the city clerk or his or her designee shall provide a signup sheet for such purposes at least 30 minutes prior to the scheduled starting time of the meeting such signup sheet shall be located on the lectern provided for speakers at the meeting no more than a total of five speakers can sign up to speak at any one meeting and each speaker shall be provided three minutes to address the mayor and city council regarding the agenda item or items to be addressed by such speaker a speaker can sign up to address more than one agenda item but the number of agenda items to be addressed by a speaker shall not affect the total amount of time allotted for each individual speaker if more than a total of five speakers sign up to speak at any one meeting the presiding officer shall only be authorized to recognize the first five persons who signed up to speak no person shall be authorized to sign up for another person to speak and no speaker shall be authorized to yield any portion of his or her unused time to another person in the event that there are a large number of persons who desire to speak on a particular agenda item the presiding officer may request that the persons wishing to speak on the agenda item select a spokesperson to address the mayor and city council on behalf of such persons a person speaking to the mayor and city council on an agenda item shall only be authorized to speak on such agenda item and any statements or comments made by such person not related to the agenda item upon which such person is authorized to speak shall be immediately ruled out of order by the presiding officer and if a speaker continues to speak on matters not related to the agenda item upon which such person is authorized to speak after being ruled out of order by the presiding officer then such person may be removed from the meeting and charged with violation of this section comments by persons speaking on an agenda item shall be directed to the presiding officer and not to individual members of the city council any speaker addressing individual member of the city council shall be ruled out of order by the presiding officer and if such speaker continues to address individual members of the city council after being ruled out of order for doing so by the presiding officer then such person may be removed from the meeting and charged with violation of this section at the conclusion of the time to speak on such agenda item each speaker shall terminate his or her remarks nothing in this subsection shall be construed to require a person to sign up to speak in connection with a public hearing to be conducted by the mayor and city council under subsection c of this section e nonagenda items members of the public desiring to bring any matter concerning the city to the attention of the city council which does not appear on a meeting agenda of the mayor and city council may submit such persons comments in writing to the city manager of the city at any time during which the city council or a council committee is not in an administrative briefing an agenda setting meeting or in a regular monthly meeting copies of such written comments from a member of the public shall be submitted to the mayor and city council within ten calendar days of the date such comments are submitted to the city manager in the event that at least three members of the city council deem it appropriate to include issues or comments submitted to the city manager under this section on the agenda of a subsequent meeting of the mayor and city council then at least three calendar days prior to the meeting of the city council at which such members desire that such item be placed upon the agenda such three members shall submit a notice to the city manager either jointly or severally to place such item on such city council meeting agenda for consideration by the mayor and city council  provided however that unless such matter is tabled or otherwise postponed by action of the governing body no such item shall be placed on an agenda of the city council more than one time every six months f meeting decorum in order to ensure proper decorum and a businesslike atmosphere at all meetings of the city council or any committee thereof no signs placards or similar displays that are larger than 17 inches by 24 inches or that are attached to sticks rods or poles or that are constructed of metal or wood shall be allowed within the city council chambers or in a city council meeting room during a city council or committee meeting unless the sign specifically illustrates depicts or describes in the form of a map plat schematic drawing picture or similar depiction a particular item that appears on the meeting agenda as an item for consideration by the city council or a committee thereof in addition to the foregoing any such sign placard or similar display that is otherwise authorized hereunder shall not be placed or displayed in a location or in a manner which blocks the view of any member of the audience city staff or the council any signs placards or similar displays that are prohibited hereunder or any sign that is otherwise authorized hereunder which blocks a persons view as prohibited herein during the course of a meeting shall be removed by the person carrying the sign upon request of the presiding officer or by an appropriate officer of the police department upon direction of the presiding officer g violations of ordinance it shall be unlawful for any person to violate the provisions of this section or for any person to disturb or interrupt any meeting of the city council or a committee thereof the use of obscene or profane language physical violence or the threat thereof or loud and boisterous behavior which the presiding officer shall determine is intended as a disruption of the meeting or any failure to comply with any lawful decision or order of the presiding officer in connection with or during the course of a meeting shall constitute a disturbance hereunder and shall be considered to be a violation of this section any person violating the provisions of this section including a person violating this section by creating a disturbance as defined herein or by failing or refusing to comply with a lawful order of the presiding officer during a meeting of the mayor and city council or a committee thereof may be ordered removed or ejected from the city council chambers or other meeting room by the presiding officer for the duration of the meeting or for such lesser period as the presiding officer shall determine in addition any person violating the provisions of this section shall upon conviction thereof be subject to punishment as provided in section 18 of this questions shall be put by the presiding officer the members shall vote by a show of hands with a majority of the members present and voting determining all questions unless otherwise provided the mayor at such officers discretion may call upon the mayor pro tem to take the chair to allow the mayor to address the council or make a motion the mayor may vote on any issue before the city council unless he is otherwise disqualified b at any meeting of the governing body of the city or any committee thereof each council member present shall vote on each question that comes before the meeting unless a city council member is immediately and particularly interested in the question to the extent that such council member has a conflict of interest or the appearance of a conflict of interest with respect to such question or unless a council member is excused from voting by a majority vote of the governing body a motion to excuse a member from voting may be made by the council member seeking to be excused must be made before the question is put to a vote and shall be decided without debate except that the council member making the motion may state briefly the reasons that the motion was made      record of votes whenever it shall be required by any one or more members the yeas and nays shall be recorded    applications etc to be written applications petitions or other settlements of claims against city agents employees a upon receipt of a claim from a person business or other entity seeking damages for personal injury or property damage resulting from the alleged intentional or negligent misconduct of the city or its agents and employees which is filed or submitted to the city in accord with ocga  36335 such claim shall be immediately transmitted to the city manager of the city for investigation and consideration upon the completion of such investigation in the event that the city manager determines that administrative adjustment or settlement of such claim is in the best interest of the city he shall be authorized to administratively adjust or settle such claim with the claimant on behalf of the city upon the following terms and conditions 1 neither the claim itself nor the administrative adjustment or settlement thereof shall exceed the sum of $100000  2 only claims for personal injury or property damage resulting from the alleged intentional or negligent misconduct by the city or its agents or employees while acting in the course of their employment with the city shall be subject to settlement pursuant to this section  3 prior to entering into the settlement of such claim in accord with the provisions hereof the city manager shall determine that administrative adjustment or settlement of such claim is in the best interest of the city will not work an economic or other hardship to the city that the claim is meritorious and that further unnecessary delay in settling such claim would be detrimental to the city  4 prior to settlement the amount claimed by the claimant shall be documented to the satisfaction of the city manager in writing and the city manager shall not be authorized to settle such claim without such documentation in an amount at least equal to the amount of the final settlement  5 the payment of all settlement proceeds shall be paid from funds previously appropriated by the city council of the town in the citys budget for the current fiscal year for the payment of such claims  6 prior to actual payment of the claim the city manager shall require the claimant to execute a full and final release in favor of the city its agents employees insurance carriers and any other person or entity who might potentially be liable to the claimant as a result of such claim such release shall also provide specifically that such release shall not be considered as an admission of any liability to the claimant by any of the releases named or referred to in the release documents  7 any and all documents required to be executed effecting such settlement shall be prepared and approved by the city attorney prior to the execution thereof and the payment of any funds pursuant thereto  8 all such settlements shall be made within 30 days of receipt of the claim by the city unless circumstances beyond the control of the city manager require a longer period of time in which case such shall be reported to the city council b the city manager shall notify the city council as soon as possible but not to exceed 15 days within the date of the completion of such administrative adjustment or settlement of the fact of adjustment or settlement and shall further maintain complete and accurate records in his office of all such matters c nothing herein shall serve to extend or shorten any statutes of limitation which may be now or hereafter applicable to any claims or claimant herein described in addition thereto nothing herein shall be construed as an attempt to alter amend change or abrogate the general provisions of state law requiring the filing of ante litum notice ocga  36336 with the city prior to the filing of suit against the city further the provisions hereof shall not be construed as in any manner changing the official or officials of the city upon whom such ante litum notice or any civil action wherein the city is a named defendant is to be served in accord with state law d nothing contained herein shall be construed to prohibit or otherwise limit the authority of the city council from settling or otherwise resolving claims filed against the city in any other manner not provided for in this section    14 8241987   procedures for sale of personal property owned by city a when the city deems it appropriate to sell personal property owned by the city the revolving loan fund of the city to be applicable to the downtown area or coextensive with the boundary of the downtown development authority area of the city 1 source of funds the economic development loan fund shall consist of federal grants from the department of housing and urban development of the united states of america program or miscellaneous income and such other funds as may be available therefor 2 object of benefit loan funds shall be used primarily to benefit the citys lowincome and moderateincome population development of the central business district within the downtown development authority boundaries 3 security security for the repayment of all loan funds shall consist of a first or second security interest in the borrowers assets whether real or personal property being financed by such loan proceeds or a security interest in whatever assets of the borrower that the city council may require in order to fully secure the economic development loan loans to a corporation shall be personally guaranteed by the shareholders of the corporation if the borrower is not the owner of the real property to be improved with said loan funds then unless otherwise authorized by the city council the owner of said real property shall guarantee repayment of said loan to the city and shall secure such guarantee by execution and delivery of a deed to secure debt with respect to such real property to the city 4 annual interest rate the interest rate shall be four percent per annum or such other interest rates that may be adopted in the future 5 maximum loan amount the maximum loan amount shall be $2500000  provided however under special circumstances whereby the city council in its sole discretion deems a larger loan is necessary to expedite the downtown development authority program in a timely manner or to bring an individual loan proposal package to completion said maximum loan amount may be exceeded by the city council the maximum loan amount shall not exceed 80 percent of the cost of the improvements financed by the loan 6 use of loan funds the use of loan funds shall be limited to a facade improvements including signage historic preservation commission approval shall be obtained where required by ordinance b interior or exterior structural improvements including roof heatingair plumbing and electrical systems or improvements thereto such systems and improvements shall become fixtures and remain with the property c provision of financial assistance by way of a loan for startup operating costs and working capital startup operating costs and working capital shall be limited to $1000000 the applicant shall provide all documentary information regarding the ownership of collateral and the market value of the collateral to be used as collateral in connection with the loan for startup operating costs and working capital the city shall be authorized to require an appraisal of such proposed collateral at the expense of the applicant and the city shall be authorized to reject such loan application should such appraisal if conducted show that the proposed collateral is of insufficient value as determined in the sole discretion of the city council to properly collateralize the proposed loan 7 length of loan no loan may be amortized or repaid over more than ten years 8 availability of loans loans shall only be made as funds are available to the city council from the economic development loan fund for such loans 9 priority a the priority for loan funds is the financing of projects that show job creation or job retention especially jobs which employ lowincome and moderateincome persons in addition for economic redevelopment activities a commitment must be made by the recipient of the loan that 51 percent of the jobs created or retained by the economic development activities financed by the loan shall be reserved for lowincome and moderateincome persons b an equal priority for loan funds is the financing of projects that will benefit lowincome and moderateincome persons such benefits shall include but shall not necessarily be limited to the financing of a project to construct or renovate a structure to be used for job training for lowincome and moderateincome persons notwithstanding the foregoing it shall be sufficient if the recipient of the loan makes a written commitment to the city where such written commitment is not prohibited by law that of the persons benefited by the project at least 51 percent of them will be lowincome and moderateincome persons c for the purposes of this section the terms lowincome persons and moderateincome persons shall be defined the same as they are periodically defined by the united states department of housing and urban development 10 selection of projects the loan review committee shall act as agent for the city in determining the selection of projects to be financed the city council shall have final approval of all such loans and all agreements made in connection therewith 11 responsibility and authority over final selection none of the policies stated herein shall be construed to restrict the city council from having full responsibility and authority over the final project selection to be financed by the downtown development authority revolving loan fund 12 repayment each loan made shall provide for the repayment of all principal and interest according to the amortization schedule approved by the city council as well as for the payment of collection costs attorneys fees court costs and penalties for late payment in such amounts as may be agreed upon by the parties 13 nonrefundable handling fee each completed loan application that is submitted for consideration must be accompanied by a nonrefundable handling fee in the amount established by ordinance that will cover the cost of credit checks copies postage and other such costs that are incurred during the application process                establishment of economic development revolving loan fund a there is hereby established an economic development revolving loan fund for the city the purpose of this fund is to assist in the creation and the retention of jobs primarily for lowincome and moderateincome persons employed or to be employed by existing or start up businesses located in the city where involvement by the city assistance to the existing or start up business is deemed necessary for the projects viability b the loan fund shall be funded with the proceeds of federal grants from the department of housing and urban development of the united states community development block grants from the state program or miscellaneous income and such other funds as may be made available by the city for such loan fund c the loan fund shall provide financial assistance for eligible activities which shall include the following 1 provision of assistance to public or private nonprofit entities in order to finance activities that will result in the direct creation or employment for lowincome or moderateincome persons 2 provision of assistance to public or private nonprofit entities in order to finance activities that will benefit lowincome and moderateincome persons such benefits shall include but shall not necessarily be limited to the financing of a project to construct or renovate a structure to be used for job training for lowincome and moderateincome persons 3 such assistance may not be in the form of outright grants although it may consist of loans interest subsidies guarantees and the financing of such activities as the a acquisition of real property  or b acquisition construction reconstruction rehabilitation or installation of buildings except for buildings for the general conduct of government such as 1 public facilities site improvements and utilities  and 2 commercial educational or industrial buildings or structures or other commercial educational or industrial real property improvements 4 provision of assistance to private forprofit entities when the assistance is necessary or appropriate to carry out an economic development project such assistance may not be in the form of outright grants although it may also consist of loans interest subsidies guarantees or technical assistance or a combination thereof in addition financial assistance to private forprofit entities shall be contingent upon firm commitments of financial participation from other sources such as private financial institutions or the private entities themselves  and must create or retain permanent jobs d passive income or real estate companies lending and investment institutions unregulated media such as newspapers and magazines speculative ventures and charitable organizations shall not be eligible to receive loan funds e regulations regarding the terms and conditions of such loans from the revolving loan fund the selection process for such loans nonrefundable handling fees repayment terms interest rate terms maximum loan amounts and other such requirements shall be established by the city council pursuant to a resolution approved by the city council for that purpose f all loans from the revolving loan fund shall be approved by the city council and no proposed loan shall be presented to the city council for such approval unless such proposal has been reviewed and approved by the staff of the city department of community and economic development under procedures authorized in the resolution establishing the policies terms and conditions pursuant to which such loans may be granted              secs 21462173  reserved division 2  annual budget footnotes  3  editors note adopted  amended div 2 in its entirety to read as herein set out former div 2  21742180 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from 56  and adopted oct 26 1992 state law reference budgets ocga  36811 et seq budgets the city council shall review and adopt an annual operating budget a capital improvement program budget and a capital budget in such form or forms as the city council may from time to time require such budgets shall be adopted by ordinance and any amendments thereto shall be adopted by ordinance  fiscal year the fiscal year of the city shall be from january 1 to december 31 of each year  preparation of proposed budget on or before a date fixed by the city council but not later than 45 days prior to the beginning of each fiscal year the city manager shall submit to the city council a proposed budget for the ensuing fiscal year which budget shall include both an operating budget and a capital budget the budget shall be accompanied by a message from the city manager containing a statement of the general fiscal policies of the city the important features of the budget explanations of major changes recommended for the next fiscal year a general summary of the budget and such other comments and information as he or she may deem pertinent the proposed budget the budget message and all supporting documents shall be filed in the office of the city clerk and shall be open to public inspection  city council action on budget a the city council may amend the budget proposed by the city manager except that the budget as finally amended and adopted must provide for all expenditures required by state law or by other provisions of the city charter and for all debt service requirements for the ensuing fiscal year and for all capital improvements required for the ensuing fiscal year and the total appropriations from any fund shall not exceed the estimated fund balance reserves and revenues b the city council by ordinance shall adopt a final budget for the ensuing fiscal year not later than the last day of the current fiscal year if the city council fails to adopt the budget by this date the amounts appropriated for the current fiscal year shall be deemed adopted for the ensuing fiscal year on a monthtomonth basis with all items prorated accordingly until such time as the city council adopts a budget for the ensuing fiscal year adoption of the budget shall take the form of an appropriations ordinance setting out the estimated revenues in detail by sources and making appropriations according to fund and by organizational unit purpose or activity as set out in the budget preparation ordinance adopted pursuant to the city charter c the amount set out in the adopted budget for each organizational unit shall constitute the annual appropriation for such and no expenditure shall be made or encumbrance created in excess of the otherwise unencumbered balance of the appropriations or allotments thereof to which it is chargeable the city council shall not authorize an expenditure for the construction of any building structure work or improvement unless the appropriations for such project are included in the capital improvements budget except to meet a public emergency as provided in the city charter or where the funds required for such improvement are otherwise provided for in accord with the city charter or applicable state laws  reserved required hearings the city council shall conduct such hearings prior to the adoption of the budget as it may deem appropriate  provided however that the hearings required by ocga  36815 and ocga  36816 and notice of such hearings as provided in such statutes shall be the minimum requirements for hearings and notice thereof in connection with the adoption of such budget unless otherwise provided by law nothing herein shall be construed to require the city council to provide a special public notice other than that required of all meetings under ocga title 50 ocga  50141 et seq with respect to any budget amendments which are considered or to be considered by the city council during any fiscal year  tax levies the city council shall annually levy by ordinance such taxes as are necessary to fund the budget the taxes and tax rates set by such ordinance shall be such that reasonable estimates of revenues from such levy shall at least be sufficient together with other budgeted revenues fund balances and applicable reserves to equal the total amount appropriated for each of the several funds set forth in the annual operating budget for defraying the expenses of the general government of the city  changes in appropriations the city manager may submit amendments to the budget of the city council at any time during the fiscal year accompanied by his or her recommendations the city council by ordinance may make changes or amendments in the appropriations contained in the current budget at any regular meeting or special or emergency meeting called for such purpose but any additional appropriations may be made only from an existing unexpended surplus any such amendments to the budget shall become effective only upon adoption by ordinance  independent annual audit there shall be an annual independent audit of all city accounts funds and financial transactions by a certified public accounted selected by the city council the audit shall be conducted according to generally accepted accounting principles any audit or any funds by the state of federal government may be accepted as satisfying the requirements of the city charter copies of all audit reports shall be available at printing costs to the public  budget officer  appointment the city manager of the city shall be and is hereby appointed budget officer of the city as authorized by ocga  36814  secs 21842198  reserved article v  purchasing agent authorized the city manager of the city shall be designated as the purchasing agent for the city and within the guidelines of this article shall prepare and promulgate administrative regulations to effect the purchasing policies of the city      policy with regard to purchasing supplies goods services and equipment to be utilized or undertaken by or on behalf of the city it shall be the policy of the city 1 to secure the best reasonable price for all supplies goods services and equipment consistent with the fiduciary role of the city  2 to secure competitive bids whenever such competitive bidding would be in the best interest of the city or whenever it is anticipated that the goods and service to be purchased will exceed $1000000 in costs to the city  however competitive bidding shall not be required either where the goods and services to be purchased are provided only by a sole source otherwise meeting the other requirements of this section or where goods and service previously purchased can be serviced updated upgraded or repaired only by a sole source otherwise meeting the requirements of this section  3 to purchase from vendors located within the city whenever the price is the lowest reasonable price or whenever the price differential is no more than five percent of the total or $30000 whichever is less  provided however in the event that there are no vendors located within the city which meet such price differential then to purchase from vendors located within the county whenever the price is the lowest reasonable price or whenever the price differential is no more than five percent of the total or $30000 whichever is less  4 to use the purchasing division of the department of administrative services of the state whenever it would be in the best interest of the city to do so  5 to award a contract for supplies goods services or equipment to the lowest responsible bidder whose bid is consistent with the quality specifications and requirements of the city with respect to the particular supplies goods services or equipment bid upon        purchase orders resulting from competitive bids in the event that competitive bidding is required whether by the city council or by the terms of this article such bids shall be advertised for and obtained as provided by law or by city ordinance acceptance of a particular bid shall be by the execution of a purchase order in accord with the provisions of this article in the event that a written contract in addition to such purchase order is required such written contract shall be approved by the city council as otherwise provided    authorized purchases all purchases of supplies goods services and equipment by the city shall be accomplished with official purchase orders in the following manner 1 regardless of whether or not a purchase of supplies goods services or equipment has been previously approved by its inclusion in the city budget for the relevant fiscal year all purchase orders for such supplies goods services and equipment which authorize a purchase in excess of $1000000 shall be approved by the city council at a regular or called meeting thereof no such purchase order or contract executed in connection therewith shall be binding upon the city or enforceable against the city unless and until the same is approved by the council as above provided 2 except as otherwise provided herein with respect to all purchase orders for the purchase of supplies goods services and equipment where such purchase order totals up to $1000000 the city manager shall be authorized to approve such purchase orders and the city shall be bound thereby 3 at his discretion the city manager shall have the authority to delegate to the department heads of the city the authority to issue purchase orders in amounts of up to $100000  provided however that such authority may be revoked at any time by the city council or by direction of the city council 4 neither the city manager nor any department head may approve a purchase order for a purchase or a service which was not provided for in the city budget for the relevant fiscal year unless such budget is amended by appropriate action of the city council to provide therefor  nor by such persons approve a purchase order which shall exceed in whole or in part the amount of funds then available in the city budget for the relevant fiscal year for the purchase or service which is the subject of such purchase order 5 the city manager shall be authorized after consultation with and approval by the mayor to approve purchases in an emergency situation without regard to the other requirements contained in this article where the immediate procurement of the purchases or services is essential to prevent delays in work undertaken by or on behalf of the city which may vitally affect the life health or convenience of the city or its citizens      limitation of citys liability the city shall not be liable for any purchase made work done or service rendered for which a purchase order has not been first issued and signed by the purchasing agent or designee as provided in this article 1   cooperative purchasing plans the city or the city purchasing agent if such purchase is otherwise authorized pursuant to this article shall have the authority to join with other units of government in cooperative purchasing plans when the best interests of the city would be served thereby 2   prohibition of interest any purchase purchase order or contract within the purview of this article in which any officer or employee of the city if financially interested either directly or indirectly shall be void except that before the execution of a purchase order or contract the city council shall have the authority to waive compliance with this section when it finds that such action is in the best interest of the city 3   authority of city council a nothing contained herein shall be construed so as to limit the authority of the mayor and city council with respect to the approval of purchases by the city or the approval of proposed contacts by such body b nothing herein shall be construed so as to alter amend modify or delete any requirement that all written contracts entered into by the city must be approved by the city council and must be executed by the mayor and attested to by the city clerk in order for the city to be bound thereby 4   purchases of landscaping materials supplies and services required by natural disaster notwithstanding the provisions of this article in the event that a natural disaster occurs within the city of americus and is so declared by the governing body of the city the city shall be authorized upon approval by the governing body of the city to purchase landscaping trees shrubs bushes plants landscaping materials landscaping services and similar items materials or services hereinafter referred to as landscaping renovations for planting installation and use upon publicly owned property damaged by such natural disaster without the necessity for competitive bidding for such landscaping renovation unless competitive bidding is required in connection with such purchases by federal or state law under the following circumstances 1 any group of local citizens interested in the landscaping needs of the city particularly as such needs relate to landscaping damages occurring to publicly owned property of the city damaged by a natural disaster which takes steps to establish and constitute themselves as an americus regreening committee consisting of either local citizens members of the governing body or a combination thereof may be recognized by the city as a private citizens committee but such committee shall be deemed to be solely a private committee and not a committee appointed by the governing body of the city and neither shall such committee be deemed to be an agency or agent of the city  2 the existence of such committee shall be reported in writing to the city manager of the city upon the establishment thereof and the city manager shall be authorized to provide such assistance including technical assistance to the committee as the city manager may deem appropriate once the committee is recognized by the city  3 such committee shall be authorized to investigate review and assess the damages and determine the required landscaping needs and landscaping renovations including determining the quantity and type of landscaping trees shrubs bushes plants landscaping materials landscaping services and similar items materials and services that are necessary in order to repair the damage to the landscaping caused by or resulting from the natural disaster with respect to such publicly owned property within the city  4 after such investigation review and assessment if the committee desires to provide its findings and recommendations to the city the committee shall review the requirements of the landscaping renovations that the committee has determined to be necessary with any local and nonlocal vendors that the committee determines have or may have the capability and qualifications to provide such landscaping renovations as the committee may determine appropriate in order that the committee may determine the best available price the best material and service availability and the vendor or vendors which can best meet the requirements found by the committee to be necessary in order to undertake and complete the landscaping renovations  5 after such determination if the committee desires to provide its findings and recommendations to the city the committee may make written recommendations to the governing body of the city regarding a the required landscaping renovations  b the cost thereof  c the vendor or vendors that the committee has determined can best meet the requirements found by the committee to be necessary in order to undertake and complete the landscaping renovations  and d any other matters that the committee may deem appropriate 6 the governing body shall be authorized to consider such recommendations and may approve disapprove or modify and approve such recommendations and if the recommendations are approved or approved with modifications by the governing body and if the landscaping renovations and purchases are to be made utilizing funds donated or granted to the city by other public agencies public foundations private entities private foundations or private individuals the committee may act as agent for the city in procuring such landscaping renovations and purchases which are approved by the governing body and the governing body shall be authorized to approve and authorize the expenditure of such donated or grant funds for such landscaping renovations and purchases without the necessity of utilizing a competitive bidding process  1021 9202007   secs 22082300  reserved article vi  identity theft prevention program short title this article shall be known as the identity theft prevention program  purpose the purpose of this article is to comply with 16 cfr  6812 in order to detect prevent and mitigate identity theft by identifying and detecting identity theft red flags and by responding to such red flags in a manner that will prevent identity theft  definitions for purposes of this article the following definitions apply city means the city of americus covered account means i an account that the city offers or maintains primarily for personal family or household purposes that involves or is designed to permit multiple payments or transactions such as a mortgage loan account utility account  and ii any other account that the city of americus offers or maintains for which there is a reasonably foreseeable risk to customers or to the safety and soundness of the city of americus from identity theft including but not limited to financial operational compliance reputation or litigation risks credit means the right granted by the city of americus to a debtor to defer payment of debt or to incur debts and defer its payment or to purchase property or services and defer payment therefor creditor means the city of americus when it regularly extends renews or continues credit  any person who regularly arranges for the extension renewal or continuation of credit  or any assignee of an original creditor who participates in the decision to extend renew or continue credit customer means a person that has a covered account with the city identity theft means a fraud committed or attempted using identifying information of another person without authority person means a natural person a corporation government or governmental subdivision or agency trust estate partnership cooperative or association personal identifying information means a persons credit card account information debit card information bank account information and drivers license information and for a natural person includes their social security number mothers birth name and date of birth red flag means a pattern practice or specific activity that indicates the possible existence of identity theft service provider means a person that provides a service directly to the city  findings a the city is a creditor pursuant to 16 cfr  6812 due to its provision or maintenance of covered accounts for which payment is made in arrears b covered accounts offered to customers for the provision of city services include utility services and community development loans c the processes of opening a new covered account restoring an existing covered account and making payments on such accounts have been identified as potential processes in which identity theft could occur d the city limits access to personal identifying information to those employees responsible for or otherwise involved in opening or restoring covered accounts or accepting payment for use of covered accounts information provided to such employees is entered directly into the citys computer system and a hard copy is filed in a secured location e the city determines that there is a low risk of identity theft occurring in the following ways if any 1 use by an applicant of another persons personal identifying information to establish a new covered account  2 use of a previous customers personal identifying information by another person in an effort to have service restored in the previous customers name  3 use of another persons credit card bank account or other method of payment by a customer to pay such customers covered account or accounts  4 use by a customer desiring to restore such customers covered account of another persons credit card bank account or other method of payment  process of establishing a covered account a as a precondition to opening a covered account with the city each applicant shall provide the city with personal identifying information of the customer for utility accounts a picture identification social security number and lease document if currently renting for loans social security number consumer credit check and financial statementstax returns applicant shall also provide any information necessary for the department providing the service for which the covered account is created to access the applicants consumer credit report such information shall be entered directly into the citys computer system and a hard copy filed in a secure storage area b each account shall be assigned an account number the city may utilize computer software to randomly generate the account number  access to covered account information a access to customer accounts shall be protected and shall be limited to authorized city personnel b such protection shall be established security module of the accounting software modifications to security shall be performed by only authorized personnel security access shall be limited to the finance director and the information system administrator c any unauthorized access to or other breach of customer accounts is to be reported immediately to the finance director and the system security changed immediately d personal identifying information included in customer accounts is considered confidential and any request or demand for such information shall be immediately forwarded to the city manager and the city attorney    credit card payments a in the event that credit card payments that are made over the internet are processed thirdparty service provider such thirdparty service provider shall certify that it has an adequate identity theft prevention program in place that is applicable to such payments b all credit card payments made over the telephone or the citys website shall be entered directly into the customers account information in the computer data base c account statements and receipts for covered accounts shall include only the last four digits of the credit or debit card or the bank account used for payment of the covered account  sources and types of red flags all employees responsible for or involved in the process of opening a covered account restoring a covered account or accepting payment for a covered account shall check for red flags as indicators of possible identity theft and such red flags shall include 1 alerts from consumer reporting agencies fraud detection agencies or service providers examples of alerts include but are not limited to a a fraud or active duty alert that is included with a consumer report  b a notice of credit freeze in response to a request for a consumer report  c a notice of address discrepancy provided by a consumer reporting agency  d indications of a pattern of activity in a consumer report that is inconsistent with the history and usual pattern of activity of an applicant or customer such as 1 a recent and significant increase in the volume of inquiries  2 an unusual number of recently established credit relationships  3 a material change in the use of credit especially with respect to recently established credit relationships  or 4 an account that was closed for cause or identified for abuse of account privileges by a financial institution or creditor 2 suspicious documents examples of suspicious documents include but are not limited to a documents provided for identification that appear to be altered or forged  b identification on which the photograph or physical description is inconsistent with the appearance of the applicant or customer  c identification on which the information is inconsistent with information provided by the applicant or customer  d identification on which the information is inconsistent with readily accessible information that is on file with the financial institution or creditor such as a signature card or a recent check  or e an application that appears to have been altered or forged or appears to have been destroyed and reassembled 3 suspicious personal identification such as suspicious address change examples of suspicious identifying information include but are not limited to a personal identifying information that is inconsistent with external information sources used by the financial institution or creditor for example 1 the address does not match any address in the consumer report  or 2 the social security number ssn has not been issued or is listed on the social security administrations death master file b personal identifying information provided by the customer is not consistent with other personal identifying information provided by the customer such as a lack of correlation between the ssn range and date of birth c personal identifying information or a phone number or address is associated with known fraudulent applications or activities as indicated by internal or thirdparty sources used by the financial institution or creditor d other information provided such as fictitious mailing address mail drop addresses jail addresses invalid phone numbers pager numbers or answering services is associated with fraudulent activity e the ssn provided is the same as that submitted by other applicants or customers f the address or telephone number provided is the same as or similar to the account number or telephone number submitted by an unusually large number of applicants or customers g the applicant or customer fails to provide all required personal identifying information on an application or in response to notification that the application is incomplete h personal identifying information is not consistent with personal identifying information that is on file with the financial institution or creditor i the applicant or customer cannot provide authenticating information beyond that which generally would be available from a wallet or consumer report 4 unusual use of or suspicious activity relating to a covered account examples of suspicious activity include but are not limited to a shortly following the notice of a change of address for an account city receives a request for the addition of authorized users on the account b a new revolving credit account is used in a manner commonly associated with known patterns of fraud patterns for example the customer fails to make the first payment or makes an initial payment but no subsequent payments c an account is used in a manner that is not consistent with established patterns of activity on the account for example where there is 1 nonpayment when there is no history of late or missed payments  2 a material change in purchasing or spending patterns d an account that has been inactive for a long period of time is used e mail sent to the customer is returned repeatedly as undeliverable although transactions continue to be conducted in connection with the customers account f the city is notified that the customer is not receiving paper account statements g the city is notified of unauthorized charges or transactions in connection with a customers account h the city is notified by a customer law enforcement or another person that it has opened a fraudulent account for a person engaged in identity theft 5 notice from customers law enforcement victims or other reliable sources regarding possible identity theft or phishing relating to covered accounts  prevention and mitigation of identity theft a in the event that any city employee responsible for or involved in restoring an existing covered account or accepting payment for a covered account becomes aware of red flags indicating possible identity theft with respect to existing covered accounts such employee shall use his or her discretion to determine whether such red flag or combination of red flags suggests a threat of identity theft if in his or her discretion such employee determines that identity theft or attempted identity theft is likely or probable such employee shall immediately report such red flags to the finance director if in his or her discretion such employee deems that identity theft is unlikely or that reliable information is available to reconcile red flags the employee shall convey this information to the finance director who may in his or her discretion determine that no further action is necessary if the finance director in his or her discretion determines that further action is necessary a city employee shall perform one or more of the following actions as determined to be appropriate by the finance director 1 contact the customer  2 make the following changes to the account if after contacting the customer it is apparent that someone other than the customer has accessed the customers covered account a change any account numbers passwords security codes or other security devices that permit access to an account  or b close the account 3 cease attempts to collect additional charges from the customer and decline to sell the customers account to a debt collector in the event that the customers account has been accessed without authorization and such access has caused additional charges to accrue  4 notify a debt collector within 48 hours of the discovery of likely or probable identity theft relating to a customer account that has been sold to such debt collector in the event that a customers account has been sold to a debt collector prior to the discovery of the likelihood or probability of identity theft relating to such account  5 notify law enforcement in the event that someone other than the customer has accessed the customers account causing additional charges to accrue or accessing personal identifying information  or 6 take other appropriate action to prevent or mitigate identity theft b in the event that any city employee responsible for or involved in opening a new covered account becomes aware of red flags indicating possible identity theft with respect an application for a new account such employee shall use his or her discretion to determine whether such red flag or combination of red flags suggests a threat of identity theft if in his or her discretion such employee determines that identity theft or attempted identity theft is likely or probable such employee shall immediately report such red flags to the finance director if in his or her discretion such employee deems that identity theft is unlikely or that reliable information is available to reconcile red flags the employee shall convey this information to the finance director who may in his or her discretion determine that no further action is necessary if the finance director in his or her discretion determines that further action is necessary a city employee shall perform one or more of the following responses as determined to be appropriate by the finance director 1 request additional identifying information from the applicant  2 deny the application for the new account  3 notify law enforcement of possible identity theft  or 4 take other appropriate action to prevent or mitigate identity theft  updating the program the governing body of the city shall annually review and as deemed necessary by the council update the identity theft prevention program along with any relevant red flags in order to reflect changes in risks to customers or to the safety and soundness of the city and its covered accounts from identity theft in so doing the governing body shall consider the following factors in exercising its discretion in amending the program 1 the citys experiences with identity theft  2 updates in methods of identity theft  3 updates in customary methods used to detect prevent and mitigate identity theft  4 updates in the types of accounts that the city offers or maintains  and 5 updates in service provider arrangements  program administration the finance director is responsible for oversight of the program and for program implementation the city manager of the city cao is responsible for reviewing reports prepared by staff regarding compliance with red flag requirements and with recommending material changes to the program as necessary in the opinion of the cao to address changing identity theft risks and to identify new or discontinued types of covered accounts any recommended material changes to the program shall be submitted to the governing body for consideration 1 the finance director will report to the cao at least annually on compliance with the red flag requirements the report will address material matters related to the program and evaluate issues such as a the effectiveness of the policies and procedures of the city in addressing the risk of identity theft in connection with the opening of covered accounts and with respect to existing covered accounts  b service provider arrangements  c significant incidents involving identity theft and managements response  and d recommendations for material changes to the program 2 the finance director is responsible for providing training to all employees responsible for or involved in opening a new covered account restoring an existing covered account or accepting payment for a covered account with respect to the implementation and requirements of the identity theft prevention program the finance director shall exercise his or her discretion in determining the amount and substance of training necessary    outside service providers in the event that the city engages a service provider to perform an activity in connection with one or more covered accounts the finance director shall exercise his or her discretion in reviewing such arrangements in order to ensure to the best of his or her ability that the service providers activities are conducted in accordance with policies and procedures agreed upon by contract that are designed to detect any red flags that may arise in the performance of the service providers activities and take appropriate steps to prevent or mitigate identity theft  treatment of address discrepancies a pursuant to 16 cfr  6811 the purpose of this section is to establish a process by which the city will be able to form a reasonable belief that a consumer report relates to the consumer about whom it has requested a consumer credit report when the city has received a notice of address discrepancy b for purposes of this section the following definitions apply 1 notice of address discrepancy means a notice sent to a user by a consumer reporting agency pursuant to 15 usc  1681ch1 that informs the user of a substantial difference between the address for the consumer that the user provided to request the consumer report and the addresses in the agencys file for the consumer 2 city means city of americus c policy in the event that the city receives a notice of address discrepancy the city employee responsible for verifying consumer addresses for the purpose of providing the city service or account sought by the consumer shall perform one or more of the following activities as determined to be appropriate by such employee 1 compare the information in the consumer report or other identifying documentation with a information the city obtains and uses to verify a consumers identity in accordance with the requirements of the customer information program rules implementing 31 usc  5318l  b information the city maintains in its own records such as applications for service change of address notices other customer account records or tax records  or c information the city obtains from thirdparty sources that are deemed reliable by the relevant city employee  or 2 verify the information in the consumer report with the consumer d furnishing consumers address to consumer reporting agency in the event that the city reasonably confirms that an address provided by a consumer to the city is accurate the city is required to provide such address to the consumer reporting agency from which the city received a notice of address discrepancy with respect to such consumer this information is required to be provided to the consumer reporting agency when 1 the city is able to form a reasonable belief that the consumer report relates to the consumer about whom the city requested the report  2 the city establishes a continuing relationship with the consumer  and 3 the city regularly and in the ordinary course of business provides information to the consumer reporting agency from which it received the notice of address discrepancy e such information shall be provided to the consumer reporting agency as part of the information regularly provided by the city to such agency for the reporting period in which the city establishes a relationship with the customer f methods of confirming consumer addresses the city employee charged with confirming consumer addresses may in his or her discretion confirm the accuracy of an address or more of the following methods 1 verifying the address with the consumer  2 reviewing the citys records to verify the consumers address  3 verifying the address party sources  or 4 using other reasonable processes  secs 23142340  reserved alcoholic beverages footnotes  1 at least three nights a week on average over the course of a calendar year  ii regularly serves prepared food with a full service kitchen consisting of a threecompartment pot sink a stove or grill permanently installed and refrigerator all of which must be approved by the health and fire departments  iii is prepared to serve food every hour it is open  iv derives at least 25 percent of its total annual gross sales from the sale of prepared meals or foods admission charges ticket sales sale of merchandise vending sales attendance fees or other recreational promotional or operational activities  v does not provide any sexually related adult entertainment at any time  vi has at least 40000 square feet of enclosed heated space  vii has an occupant capacity of at least 3500  viii is located on a major thoroughfare  ix does not provide the sale of alcohol on sundays unless such establishment qualifies for sunday sales under state law and the provisions of this chapter of the americus ordinances  and x does not allow the admission of any natural person who is under the age of 21 years of age during hours when alcohol is served except in accordance with the provisions of section 690 of this chapter indoor entertainment halls shall be allowed to sell alcoholic beverages sales license means the authorization by the mayor and city council to engage in the sale of alcoholic beverages either by the package or consumption on the premises license review board means the board created by the governing body of the city of americus 1 there is hereby established a license review board 2 the license review board established by this section shall have the following duties a to hear due cause hearings as provided in chapter 6 of this to consider and act upon any matters specifically delegated to the license review board by any other city ordinance or resolution or action of the city council 3 applicants or licensee shall be given notice of the date time and place when the license review board will consider the respective matter 4 the license review board other than as expressly provided in chapter 6 shall have no authority or jurisdiction to hear consider or render decisions of any kind with respect to the suspension revocation probation or other disciplinary action against a license or licensee 5 any decision or recommendation of the license review board may be appealed to the city council pursuant to section 663 any decision or recommendation of the license review board not appealed to the mayor and council must be approved by the city council or set down for a second due cause hearing before the city council 6 the decision of the city council on an appeal under this article shall be final unless appeal is made to the superior court of the county any aggrieved party may appeal a decision of the city council by filing a petition for writ of certiorari to the superior court within 30 days of the decision of the city council 7 the license review board shall have no jurisdiction or authority to hear any appeal from or to reverse modify or set aside any decision of the city council 8 the license review board members shall be appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the mayor and city council and shall be composed of five members three members of the license review board will serve twoyear terms and two members will serve oneyear terms 9 if there is a vacancy on the license review board by virtue of a member resigning or for any other reason then the mayor shall appoint a replacement for the vacant position the replacement shall serve temporarily until the city council ratifies such appointment and in such case the replacement for that position shall become permanent if the council fails to ratify such replacement then the mayor shall appoint a different replacement until a new member for that position is appointed and ratified as provided herein 10 by majority vote the city council may terminate any term of a license review board member prior to the expiration of such term terms of service by any board member shall terminate at the end of their respective terms any member of the license review board may be reappointed by the city council subject to the consecutive term rule below there shall be a three consecutive term limit on the number of times such terms can be renewed after three terms the member is required to sit out one term prior to being reconsidered for a subsequent appointment 11 the license review board shall meet at such times as necessary to be determined by such board and shall render decisions in public on the date of the consideration by the board the decision shall then be memorialized in writing and delivered to the affected parties after such decision is announced in public 12 the license review board shall select one of its members to serve as chair and one of its members to serve as secretary to serve at the pleasure of the license review board minutes and records of all proceedings shall be kept and maintained in the office of the city clerk 13 each member of the license review board shall either be a resident of the city or have an ownership interest as principal shareholder general partner or sole proprietor in at least one business that is located in the city no employee or elected official of the city shall be appointed to the board the mayor may appoint and the city council may ratify the appointment of any person who is an alcoholic beverage license holder provided that only three such license holders if any serve on the board licensee means a person holding any class of license issued under the terms of this chapter lounge means a separate room in which alcoholic beverages are sold connected with a part of and adjacent to a restaurant or located in a hotel as defined in this section with all booths stools and tables being unobstructed and open to view all lounges shall be air conditioned and have a seating capacity of at least 50 people a lounge as defined in this section which is operated on a different floor in the premises or in a separate building or is not connected to or adjacent to a restaurant shall be considered a separate establishment and shall pay an additional license fee therefor malt beverage means any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of any infusion or lager beer small beer and strong beer the term beer and malt beverage are interchangeable throughout this chapter the term does not include sake known as japanese rice wine managing capacity means the 3 in the case of wine any vintner minor means any natural person less than 18 years of age nightclub means an establishment having a seating capacity of at least 100 people with all booths and tables being unobstructed and open to view deriving its primary income from the sales of alcoholic beverages and providing to its patrons a band andor other professional live entertainment performed onsite including but not limited to music comedy readings dancing or acting all nightclubs shall be equipped with air conditioning and shall maintain an adequate kitchen with a sufficient number of servers and employees for cooking preparing and serving food and meals for their patrons provided that nightclubs located in hotels having dining room and kitchen facilities may be excluded from the requirement of maintaining a kitchen in connection with such nightclub the principal business of such nightclubs shall be entertainment and the serving of food and spirituous liquors shall be principal shareholders under the definition of that term contained in this section pouring license means a license that authorizes onpremises consumption of alcoholic beverages principal shareholder means a person who owns any shares of a corporation with less than 35 shareholders  or if the corporation has more than 35 shareholders a person who owns more than five percent of the shares of the corporation except that a person who owns shares which are publicly traded shall not be deemed to be a principal shareholder or to have a beneficial interest in the corporation based solely on the fact of stock ownership principal shareholder shall also include a person who owns any membership interests in a limited liability company with less than 35 members  or if the limited liability company has more than 35 members a person who owns more than five percent of the outstanding membership interests in the limited liability company private club means a nonprofit association organized and existing under the laws of the state actively in operation within the city which has been in existence at least one year prior to the filing of its application for a license to be issued under this chapter  and which complies with all requirements set forth in this section it has at least 75 members who regularly pay monthly quarterly or semiannual dues  and it is organized and operated exclusively for pleasure recreation and other nonprofit purposes  and no part of its net earnings inure to the benefit of any shareholders or members  and it owns hires or leases a building or space therein for the reasonable use to its members with suitable kitchen and dining room space and equipment  and it maintains and uses a sufficient number of servers and employees for cooking preparing and serving meals for its members and guest  provided that no member or officer agent or employee of the club is paid or receives directly or indirectly in the form of salary or other compensation any profits from the sale of spirituous liquors to the club or its members or guests beyond the amount of such salary as may be fixed by its members at any annual meetings or by its governing board out of the general revenue of the club private party function means an event held where alcoholic beverages are provided the licensee must submit to and have the private party function approved by the supervisor of the citys business license office provided such function does not threaten the health safety and welfare of the participants or public in the event the private party function is not approved by the business license supervisor the licensee may appeal said decision to the mayor and city council the mayor and city council shall have authority to approve the private party function provided the function does not threaten the health safety and welfare of the participants or public private residence means a house or dwelling wherein not less than one or more than two families in a commercial zone properly sanitized means the container was sanitized per the instructions of star san sanitizer or any product that is the equivalent of star san sanitizer  or placed in an oven at a temperature of 340 degrees or higher for at least 60 minutes  or washed in an automatic dishwasher for a full wash and heat dry cycle with or without the addition of detergent agents  or sanitized in conformance with the sanitation requirements for glassware used in restaurants as set forth in the rules or regulations of the sumter county health department purchase price means the
