article shall be known as the city sidewalk installation article  18201 3222007 definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section as follows city block is the smallest area that is surrounded by public streets within the incorporated area of the city lot owners means the owner or owners of record of each lot abutting a proposed sidewalk whether or not there is constructed on such lot a dwelling house commercial building or other structure such term shall include both personal and business owners of such lots of record petition means a petition as more particularly described in section 78203 of this article  18202 3222007 petition a whenever any lot owner or owners located within the corporate limits of the city desire to request the city to install a sidewalk fronting the property owned by such lot owner or owners along one or more sides of a city block then such lot owner or owners shall notify the city clerk who shall provide the lot owner or owners with a preprinted petition which petition shall be for the purpose of ascertaining the level of support for the installation of such sidewalk at the time of providing the petition to the lot owner or owners the city clerk shall determine an estimated installation cost of the proposed sidewalk which cost shall be assessed to each lot owner in a prorated amount as established in this article and such estimated cost shall be provided to the lot owner or owners requesting the application b such petition shall have typed thereon a title which shall be petition requesting the city of americus to install a sidewalk along the ____________ side of ____________ street from ____________ street to ____________ street there shall further be typed thereon the following statement at the top of each page of the petition the undersigned by signing this petition do hereby request the city of americus to install a sidewalk as described above the undersigned have been informed and do understand that if at least 75 percent of the record owners of lots abutting such proposed sidewalk sign this petition the governing body of the city may authorize the installation of such sidewalk and each record owner of a lot or lots abutting said sidewalk shall be required to pay the prorated cost of installation of such sidewalk as established by city ordinance c such petition shall thereafter have spaces for the printed name and address the legal signature and the date of signing for each lot owner who signs such petition such petition shall be returned to the city clerk within 90 calendar days of the date that the petition was delivered by the city clerk to the lot owner or owners requesting such petition no such petition shall be returned to or accepted by the city clerk until at least 75 percent of the record lot owners abutting the proposed sidewalk shall have signed the petition for purposes of ascertaining the 75 percent threshold the following shall apply 1 a lot owner may be counted as signing the petition only once regardless of the number of lots such lot owner may own abutting said sidewalk 2 where property is owned by more than one person the signature of only one such owner shall be counted in calculating such 75 percent 3 persons who rent or lease property abutting such proposed sidewalk may sign such petition but their signatures shall not be counted toward the 75 percent threshold 4 where the lot owner is a corporation or other legal entity the petition shall only be signed by an authorized officer or agent of the corporation d upon submission of said petition as a single petition to the city clerk the city clerk shall cause the signatures thereon to be verified the city clerk shall validate the petition by verifying that the proper number of signatures is contained on the petition and that the persons signing the petition are owners of real property abutting said proposed sidewalk as required by this article in the event that the city clerk determines that the petition is invalid for any reason or if the application does not contain sufficient signatures the application shall be returned to the person or persons submitting such application and it shall not be subject to further consideration by the governing body until such time as a new application is submitted and the city clerk validates the new application any persons who are not record owners of lots abutting the proposed sidewalk or who are otherwise not authorized to sign such petition or have their signatures counted shall have their names stricken from the petition and shall not be counted for purposes of ascertaining the 75 percent threshold e if after verification of the signatures the city clerk determines that at least 75 percent of the lot owners owning real property abutting the proposed sidewalk have signed the petition then said petition shall be presented to the governing body of the city at its next regular monthly meeting for consideration in the event that the petition contains the properly verified signatures of at least 75 percent of the persons owning real property abutting the proposed sidewalk the city council shall be authorized to approve the installation of the sidewalk but the city council shall not be required to approve such installation f if the installation of such sidewalk is approved by the city council the appropriate city departments shall proceed with the installation of such sidewalk which installation shall be performed in accord with applicable building and other codes g the city shall provide all labor and materials required for the installation of the sidewalk at the conclusion of the installation the city clerk shall determine the actual total installation cost incurred by the city including but not limited to  the cost of labor materials rightofway acquisition surveys and engineering costs such cost shall be determined within 30 calendar days of the completion of the installation the finance director shall then determine the cost of the installation per linear foot and shall cause each lot owner abutting such subdivision to be billed an amount equal to such cost per linear foot times the number of linear feet owned by such lot owner abutting the installed sidewalk such bills shall be paid by the lot owners within 30 days of submission by the city in the event that it is requested by one or more lot owners and approved by the governing body and in lieu of payment of such cost of installation in one payment as to any lot owner or owners so requesting the city shall be authorized to bill each lot owner for such lot owners prorated cost over a 12month period  provided however that any lot owner requesting to be billed over a 12month period shall also pay interest equal to one percent per month on the unpaid principal balance until all payments are paid in full the sale of the lot prior to the lot owners payment of such prorated cost shall not relieve the lot owner of the obligation to pay such cost in full as required by this article failure to pay any installment when due shall entitle the city to terminate utility services to the lot owner in the same manner as if the lot owner had failed to pay a city utility bill nothing herein shall prohibit the city from including the billing for the prorata share of the installation of such sidewalk to the lot owners in the lot owners monthly utility bill  18203 3222007 application acceptance  rightofways a the city shall not be required to install such sidewalk unless the city obtains from each lot owner a deed to such real property as the city may require in order for the city to construct said sidewalk such rightofway shall be conveyed to the city in fee simple and at no cost or expense to the city b no application for the construction of a sidewalk shall be accepted by the city clerk hereunder unless such application includes the construction and paving of a sidewalk for the distance of at least one side of a city block c no application shall be accepted by the city clerk hereunder for the repaving of an existing paved sidewalk  18204 3222007 maintenance and upkeep upon completion of the installation of the sidewalk the city shall assume responsibility for the maintenance and upkeep thereof  18205 3222007 prohibition nothing in this article shall be construed to prohibit the city from undertaking to construct sidewalks at such locations as the city may deem appropriate and in the best interest of the city and its citizens regardless of whether a petition as described in section 78203 hereof has been submitted to the city any such construction by the city shall be undertaken and completed at the sole cost and expense of the city  18206 3222007 secs 7820778300  reserved article viii  improper use of public or private property urban camping and improper use of public property a it shall be unlawful for any person to sleep lie down to reside upon or to store personal property in any park in any cemetery upon any sidewalk or in or upon any public property of the city b it shall be unlawful for any person to use any public park cemetery public sidewalk or public property for living accommodations or for camping except in areas specifically designated for such use c it shall be unlawful for any person other than the owner tenant employee or other person with permission from the owner to camp sleep reside store personal property upon or lie down outside upon any private property without the owners permission to do so d notwithstanding the provisions of this section this section shall not apply to the following 1 persons sitting or lying down as a result of a medical emergency  2 persons sitting in wheelchairs while using parks sidewalks or other public places  3 persons sitting down while attending parades for which valid permits have been issued  4 persons sitting down while patronizing outdoor cafes  5 persons sitting on chairs or benches supplied by a public agency or by an abutting private property owner  provided however that such exception shall not apply to persons sleeping lying down residing upon or storing personal property upon such chairs or benches  6 persons sitting down or lying down while attending sporting events performances festivals and concerts taking place in any park or upon any street or sidewalk where such event is authorized by the city  7 children under the age of 13 years sleeping in parks while being carried by or accompanied by another person over such age or while sitting or lying in a baby stroller or carriage  8 persons offering the sale of merchandise food vegetables fruit produce and similar items from the sidewalk in front of a business where such sale is otherwise authorized by the city e a person convicted of violating this or a person entering a plea of guilty or nolo contendre to a violation of this shall be punished as provided in section 18 of the city day that a person violates this shall be considered to be a separate offense in no event shall a violation of this be considered or held to be a lesser included offense of the offense of loitering as provided in section 62114 of the city  subdivisions article i  in general definitions  street classifications the following words terms and phrases when used in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning alleys means minor ways used primarily for vehicular services access to the rear or sides of commercial or industrial properties collector streets means a street used to carry traffic from minor streets to major streets including the principal entrance streets to a neighborhood or group development and streets for circulation within such neighborhood or development streets are as defined in section 12 and for the purposes of these regulations streets are classified as follows major streets means a street used primarily for fast or heavy traffic minor streets means a street used primarily for access to the abutting properties subdivision 1 the term subdivision means any division of a tract or parcel of land into two or more lots building sites or other divisions for the purpose whether immediate or the future sale legacy or building development and includes any division of land involving a new street or a change in one or more existing streets and includes resubdivision and where appropriate to the context relates to the process of subdividing or to the land or area subdivided 2 provided however the following are not included in this definition a the subdivision of land for agricultural purposes provided no lot thereby produced is less than five acres or no new street is involved b the sale or exchange of parcels of land between owners of adjoining properties provided that additional lots are not thereby created and that the lots created are in accordance with other city regulations c the division of land into parcels where no new street is to be established and the resulting lots are equal to or larger than the standard required in the city and a zoning classification of resulting lots remains the same as the zoning classification of the land before such division  provided however that nothing herein shall be construed to prevent the rezoning of such property on proper application and approval granted in accordance with this    zoning  conflict of standards a no final plat of land within the force and effect of an existing zoning regulations will be approved unless it conforms with such regulations b whenever there is a discrepancy between minimum standards or building code or other official standards the highest standard shall apply    variances where the subdivider can show that a provision of these standards would cause unnecessary hardship if strictly adhered to and where because of topographical or other conditions peculiar to the site in the opinion of the planning commission a departure may be made without destroying the intent of such provisions the planning commission may authorize a variance any variance thus authorized is to be stated in writing in the minutes of the planning commission with the reasoning on which the departure was justified set forth    enforcementauthorities designated  duties the provisions of this chapter shall be administered and enforced by the community development director and the planning commission the community development director shall 1 receive all subdivision plats  2 in cooperation with the planning commission review and approve or disapprove subdivision plats  3 inspect subdivisions for compliance with the requirement of this chapter and other applicable city ordinances    samecircumventing requirements  approval of plat required  access street required a the owner or agent of the owner of any land to be subdivided within the city who transfers or sells or agrees to sell negotiates to sell such land by reference to or exhibition of or by other use of a plat to subdivide such land before such plat has been approved by the planning commission and recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court of this county shall be denied all building permits public services and utility connections and subject to punishment for ordinance violation and the description by metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer or other document used in the process of selling or transfer shall not exempt the transaction from such penalties the city attorney or other official designated by the city council may enjoin such transfer or sale or agreement by appropriate action b no plat or plan of subdivision within the city shall be filed or recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court of this county until it has been approved by the planning commission and such approval entered in writing on the plat by the secretary of the planning commission c no building permit shall be issued for and no building or other structure shall be erected on any lot within the city unless the street giving access to the lot upon which said building is proposed to be placed shall be accepted or opened as or shall have otherwise received the legal status of a public street prior to that time or unless such street corresponds in its location and line with a street shown on a subdivision plat approved by said planning commission or with a street located and accepted by the city any building erected in violation of this section shall be deemed an unlawful structure and the building official city attorney or other official designated by the city council may bring appropriate action to enjoin such erection or cause it to be vacated or removed    preliminary plat filing fee the developer shall be assessed a filing fee in the amount established by ordinance payable to the finance director at the time of filing the preliminary plat      secs 8278230  reserved article ii  procedures for plat approval generally a the procedure for formal review and approval of a subdivision plat shall consist of the following three separate steps 1 the subdivider should consult early and informally with the community development director andor other city technical staff for advice and assistance before the preparation of the preliminary sketch plat and its formal application for approval this will enable the subdivider to become thoroughly familiar with these standards the major street plan and other official plans or public improvements that might affect the area such informal review should prevent unnecessary and costly revisions 2 prior to the making of any street improvement or installations of utilities the developer shall submit to the planning commission a preliminary plat of the proposed subdivision after receiving the planning commissions approval of the preliminary plat and full concurrence and approval by the city the developer may then proceed to grade the streets and install all improvements required by this chapter and any other applicable city ordinances in lieu of the completion of all improvements prior to submission of the final plat the developer may post a bond with the city or certified check in an amount and with surety satisfactory to the city and conditions satisfactory to the city providing for and securing to the city the actual construction and installation of such improvements within a period specified by the planning commission and stated in the bond 3 after completion of the physical development of the subdivision or the posting of a bond or certified check to guarantee the same the developer shall submit to the planning commission a final plat together with any required certificates the final plat along with any deed restrictions becomes the instrument to be recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court of this county b no final subdivision plat shall be approved by the planning commission or accepted for record by the office of the clerk of the superior court of this county until the required improvements listed shall be constructed in satisfactory manner and approved by the appropriate approving agent    preliminary plat a at least ten days prior to the regular meeting of the planning commission the subdivider shall submit to the building officials office three copies of the plat of the proposed subdivision drawn to a scale of not less than one inch equals 100 feet along with a receipt for the filing fee from the finance director b the preliminary plat shall meet the minimum standards of design and general requirements for the construction of public improvements as set forth in article iii of this chapter and shall give the following information insofar as possible 1 description a proposed name of subdivision b name and address of subdivider c graphic scale north point and date the north point shall be identified as magnetic true or grid north d location sketch map showing the relationship of the subdivision site to the surrounding area including directions and distances to readily identifiable landmarks in the surrounding area e acreage to be subdivided 2 existing conditions a topography by contours at vertical intervals of not more than two feet or as determined necessary by the city utilities director when a new street is involved in a subdivision including outline of wooded areas and classifications of land b zoning district classification on land to be subdivided and of adjoining land c names and addresses of adjoining property owners or subdivisions d in case of resubdivision a copy of existing plat with proposed resubdivision superimposed thereon e location of streams lakes and swamps and land subject to flood as determined from past history of flooding listed on appropriate fema map f location of existing and platted property lines location width and names of all platted roads railroads utility rightsofway public areas existing buildings or structures g existing sewers water mains drains culverts or other underground facilities within the tract or within the rightofway of boundary roads with sizes grades and invert elevations from public records or from field surveys or other sources all sizes and data on all utilities shall be provided h certification by the county health officer when individual sewage disposal or water systems are to be installed 3 proposed conditions a layout of roads alleys and public crosswalks with widths road names or designations b layout of all lots and the area of each lot including building setback lines and lot divisions with scaled dimensions and utility easements with width and use on all lots c preliminary plan of all utilities to be constructed d designation of all land to be reserved or dedicated for public use c within 30 days after submission of the preliminary plat the planning commission shall review it and indicate its approval disapproval or approval subject to listed modifications as a basis for preparation of the final plat if a plat is disapproved reasons for such disapproval will be stated in the records of the planning commission failure of the planning commission to act on the preliminary sketch within 30 days will be deemed approval of this plat unless the developer agrees to an extension of time d approval of the preliminary plat by the planning commission shall not constitute acceptance of the final plat and shall not be indicated on the preliminary plat e the approval of the preliminary plat shall lapse until a final plat based thereon is submitted within one year from the date of such approval unless an extension of time is applied for and granted by the planning commission f after the planning commission has reviewed and acted on the preliminary plat one copy will be returned to the developer one copy will go to the building officials office and one copy will be retained in the records of the planning commission g after the planning commission has approved the preliminary plat construction plans should be submitted to the building official and include the following 1 layout of roads alleys and public crosswalks with widths road names or designations grades and cross sections 2 preliminary plan of sanitary sewers with grades service pipe size and points of discharge together with certified copy of all load design factors and computations 3 preliminary plan of storm drainage system with glade pipe size and location of outlet together with certified copy of all design factors and computations 4 preliminary plan of water supply system with pipe sizes and location of hydrants valves and all appurtenances      final plat a at least ten days prior to the regular meeting of the planning commission the subdivider shall submit to the building officials office an original on reproducible mylar or vellum and three copies of the final plat the final plat shall conform substantially to the preliminary plat as approved and if desired by the subdivider it may constitute only that portion of the preliminary plat which such developer proposes to record and develop at the time provided however that such portion conforms to all requirements of these standards b the original shall be drawn to a scale of not less than one inch equals 100 feet on reproducible mylar or vellum and shall correspond to plat book dimensions it shall be the developers responsibility to provide the clerk of superior court with a plat that will fit in the plat bookcabinet when more than one sheet is required an index sheet of the same size shall be filed showing the entire subdivision with sheets lettered in alphabetical order as a key c when the plat has been approved the original will be returned to the developer with the approval of the planning commission certified thereon for filing with the clerk of the superior court of this county  one copy will be returned to the developer for such developers records  one copy will be forwarded to the building officials office and one copy will be returned in the records of the planning commission d the planning commission shall approve or disapprove this final plat within 30 days after its submission to that body failure of the planning commission to act on this final plat within these 30 days shall be deemed approval of it if the plat is disapproved the grounds for disapproval shall be stated upon the records of the planning commission e approval of the final plat by the planning commission shall not constitute acceptance by the public of the dedication of any streets or public ways or ground f the final plat shall comply with the plat act and shall give the following information 1 certification that the applicant is the landowner all parties with mortgage or lien interest to be included and that applicant dedicates street rightsofway and any sites for public use 2 certification by a licensed surveyor to the accuracy of survey and plat and placement of monuments 3 certification by the proper city officials that the developer has complied with the following all improvements have been installed in accord with the requirements of this chapter and other applicable city ordinances 4 protective covenants or deed restrictions if any shall be placed directly on the final plat or attached thereto in form for recording 5 certificate on the plat to be signed by the secretary of the planning commission when the plat has been given final approval by the planning commission      asbuilt construction plans a the asbuilt construction plans shall give the following information 1 sufficient information to reproduce the plat on the ground including tract boundary lines and their relation to established land lot lines rightofway property lines of residential lots and other sites with accurate dimensions to the nearest onehundredth of a foot bearings and angles on all lines radii arcs and central angles of all curves with readings to the nearest minute 2 profiles of grades for streets when required by the city 3 blocks designated by letter and lots by number or lots numbered consecutively 4 location and description of monuments 5 final plan of sanitary sewers with grade pipe sizes and point of discharge 6 final plan of storm drains with grade pipe sizes and point of discharge 7 final plan of water supply system with pipe sites and location of hydrants and valves b the asbuilt construction plans shall be furnished to the public works department on a 312inch disk or cd and shall be in a dwg or dxf format      secs 82358256  reserved article iii  requirements and standards basic requirements  minimum standards a land which the planning commission has found to be unsuitable for subdivision due to flooding bad drainage steep slopes rock formations or other features likely to be harmful to the safety health and general welfare of the future residents shall not be subdivided unless adequate methods approved by the planning commission are formulated by the developer for meeting the problems created by the subdivision of such land b land subject to flooding shall not be platted for residential occupancy or for such other uses as will not comply with chapter 34 article ii the danger to health life and property unless such land is not to be used as a building site in applying this provision land liable to flooding as determined from past history shall be considered subject to flood fill shall not be used to raise the land in areas subject to flood unless the fill proposed does not restrict the flow of water and unduly increase flood heights    streets a conformity to the major street plan the location and width of all streets and roads shall conform to the official major street plan  ie provision must be made for the location of thoroughfares as shown on the major street plan b relation to adjoining street system the proposed street system shall extend existing streets at the same or greater width but in no case less than the required minimum width it shall connect with streets already dedicated in adjacent subdivisions or where no such streets exist it shall follow the projection of streets in related subdivided tracts so that other subdivisions may connect therewith the city reserves the right to require the developer to meet minimum road design standards c restriction of access when a tract fronts on an arterial street or highway the planning commission may require all residential lots to be provided with frontage on a minor residential street d street rightofway widths the minimum width of rightofway measured from lot line to lot line shall be as shown on the major street plan or if not shown on such plan shall be not less than as follows 1 arterial streets and highways 80 to120 feet 2 collector streets 60 feet 3 commercial and industrial streets 80 feet 4 minor residential streets a curb and gutter 50 feet b ditches 60 feet for both of the above a 15foot utility drainage easement shall be provided on each side of the rightofway e exceptions in cases where topography or other physical conditions made a street of the required minimum width impracticable the planning commission may modify the above requirements through proposed business areas the street widths shall be increased ten feet on each side if needed to provide parking without interference to normal passing traffic f additional width on existing street subdivisions that join existing streets shall dedicate additional rightsofway if needed to meet the above minimum street width requirements 1 the entire rightofway shall be provided where any part of the subdivision is on both sides of the existing street 2 when the subdivision is located on only one side of an existing street onehalf of the required rightofway measured from the centerline of the existing roadway shall be provided g street grades and elevations grades on major streets shall not exceed seven percent and grades on other streets shall not exceed 12 percent h horizontal curves where a deflection angle of more than two degrees in the alignment of a street occurs a curve of reasonably long radius shall be introduced on streets 60 feet or more in width the centerline radius of curvature shall be not less than 300 feet  on other streets it shall not be less than 100 feet i vertical curves all changes in grade shall be connected by vertical curves of minimum length in feet equal to 15 times the algebraic difference in rates of grade for major streets and onehalf this minimum length for other streets profiles of all streets showing natural and finished grades drawn to a scale of not less than one inch equals 100 feet horizontally and one inch equals 20 feet vertically may be required by the planning commission upon recommendation of the city utilities director j intersections street intersections shall be as nearly at right angles as possible and no intersection shall be at an angle of less than 60 degrees property line radii at street intersections shall not be less than 20 feet and where the angle of street intersection is less than 75 degrees the planning commission may require a greater curb radius to permit the construction of a curb having a desirable radius without curtailing the sidewalk at a street corner to less than normal width the property line at such street corner shall be reduced or otherwise set back sufficiently to permit such construction k tangents a tangent of at least 100 feet long shall be introduced between reverse curves on all streets l street jogs street jogs with centerline offsets of less than 125 feet shall not be allowed m deadend streets 1 minor terminal streets or courts designed to have one end permanently closed shall be no more than 600 feet long unless necessitated by topography they shall be provided at the closed end with a turnaround having an outside roadway diameter of at least 90 feet and a street rightofway diameter of at least 110 feet for curb and gutter and 130 feet for ditches 2 where phases may be proposed a temporary turnaround shall be provided n private streets and reserve strips there shall be no private streets platted in any subdivision every lot of subdivided property shall be served from a publicly dedicated street there shall be no reserve strips controlling access to streets except where the control of such strips is definitely placed with the city under conditions approved by the planning commission o street names proposed streets that are obviously in alignment with others already existing and named shall bear the names of existing streets in no case shall the names for proposed streets duplicate names of existing streets irrespective of the use of the suffix street avenue boulevard driveway place or court p alleys alleys shall be provided to the rear of all lots used for business purposes  alleys shall not be provided in residential blocks except where the subdivider produces evidence satisfactory to the planning commission of the need for alleys q construction requirements 1 every subdivision developer shall be required to make adequate provision for handling drainage problems to grade and improve streets and alleys to install curbs or invert ditches and to install street name signs in accordance with specifications established by the city utilities director 2 all street design and construction and related matters shall be in strict accordance with georgia department of transportation standard specifications volume 1 construction of roads and bridges and volume 2 materials for roads and bridges and all revisions thereto where circumstances dictate variations from the standard specifications the city utilities director may vary the requirements providing the design or materials accepted are in all ways commensurate with good practice 3 all materials equipment labor and other matters related to street construction shall be provided by the developer the following is a summary of the improvements required a grading all streets roads and alleys shall be graded to their full width by the subdivider so that pavements and sidewalks if installed in the future can be constructed on the same level plane the preparation of the rightofway before grading is started and the construction of cuts and fills shall be accomplished according to the specifications of the city b storm drainage an adequate drainage system including necessary curbs pipes culverts headwalls intersectional drains drop inlets bridges swale ditches etc shall be provided for the proper drainage of all surface water c installation of utilities after grading is completed and approved and before any base is applied all of the underground work water mains gas mains etc and all service connections shall be installed completely and approved throughout the length of the road and across the flat section all driveways for houses to be built by the developer shall be cut and drained d roadway base after preparation of the subgrade the roadbed shall be properly based with one of the following 1 a sixinch sand clay base class b  2 a sixinch graded aggregate base  or 3 sixinch mixed in place soil cement base e roadway surfacing the paved surface shall be a twoinch compacted asphalt plant mix f minimum pavement width minimum pavement including paved gutters between curbs shall be as follows 1 minor residential streets 30 feet 2 access routes 38 to 44 feet 3 arterial streets or as may be required 4 ditch sections 24 feet g curbs where the subdivider elects to provide curbs or it is deemed essential and necessary by the city utilities director a permanent sixinch portland cement concrete curb and gutter with a longitudinal storm drain system shall be installed backfill shall slope toward the curb to ensure drainage of surface water into the storm drainage system h rural ditch section where the developer does not install curb and gutter a rural ditch section shall be provided said ditch shall be constructed with a minimum of  slope on both sides of the ditch and shall have a minimum channel width of at least two feet all rural ditch sections shall be designed and constructed to accommodate a 25year flood no rural ditch section shall be constructed within a rightofway less than 60 feet wide with a 15foot utilitystorm drainage easement on both sides all rural ditch sections shall be seeded or sodded to provide for a permanent stand of grass i outfall ditches outfall ditches shall be piped 130 feet from the rightofway    blocks a in general blocks shall be not less than 400 feet nor more than 1200 feet in length except where topography or other conditions peculiar to the site make such dimensions impracticable b blocks shall be wide enough to allow two tiers of lots of minimum depth except where fronting on major streets or prevented by topography conditions or size of the property in which case the planning commission will approve a single tier or lots of minimum depth    a arrangement insofar as practical side lot lines shall be at right angles to straight street lines or radial to curved street lines each lot shall front upon a public street or road that is not less than 50 feet in width each lot shall be at least 30 feet in width at the front property line b minimum size the size shape and orientation of lots shall be such as the planning commission deems appropriate for the type of development and use contemplated where a public sanitary sewer is reasonably accessible the subdivider shall connect with such sewer and provide a connection to each lot where a public sewer is not accessible an alternate method of sewage disposal may be used when meeting all applicable public health regulations 1 residential lots served by a public sewer system shall be not less than 60 feet wide at the building setback line nor less than 7000 square feet in area where a rural ditch section is used each lot shall maintain a 100foot width at the setback line not less than 13000 square feet in size and maintain a minimum frontage at the rightofway line of 50 feet where a culdesac is constructed using the rural ditch section method the maximum number of lots on a culdesac shall be five lots with a minimum rightofway diameter of 130 feet and a minimum paving diameter being 90 feet 2 for residential lots not served by a public sewer system the planning commission shall require that data from percolation tests be submitted as a basis for approving subdivisions dependent upon septic tanks as a means of sewage disposal and no lot shall be less than 100 feet wide at the building line nor less than 15000 square feet in area 3 for residential lots not served by a public water supply or a public sewer system no lot shall be less than 100 feet wide at the building line nor less than one acre in size except upon approval of the county health officer and in no case shall any lot be less than onehalf acre in size 4 the minimum size of residential lots to be served by a private source of water supply shall be determined by the county health officer after investigations of soil conditions proposed sewer system and depth of groundwater 5 size of properties reserved or laid out for commercial or industrial properties shall be adequate to provide for the offstreet service and parking facilities required by the type of use and development contemplated platting of individual lots shall be avoided in favor of an overall design of the land to be used for such purposes 6 the size and widths of lots shall in no case be less than the minimum requirements of the zoning regulations in effect c building setback lines the minimum depth of building setback lines from any street shall be 30 feet if however suitable provision is made in connection with the plat or restrictions pertaining to the plat building lines may be varied provided such variation does not reduce the setback more than five feet where rural ditch section construction for a subdivision is used the minimum building setback line from any street rightofway shall be 50 feet for any zoning district d corner lots corner lots shall be sufficiently wider and larger to permit the additional side yard requirements of the zoning regulations or building setback lines outlined above    utilities a water water mains for both domestic use and fire protection shall be properly connected with the city water system the lines shall conform with accepted standards of good practice for municipal water systems and shall meet as a minimum the requirements of the state environmental protection division and the city all materials labor equipment and other matters related to the water distribution system shall be provided by the developer b sewer when the subdivision is located within the service area of a public sewer system sanitary sewers shall be installed in such a manner as to serve adequately all lots with connection to the public system where lots cannot be economically connected with a sewer system they must contain adequate area for the installation of approved septic tank and disposal fields and must be approved in writing by the county health officer all materials equipment labor and other matters related to the sanitary sewer system shall be provided by the developer and all sewer facilities shall be installed in accordance with the standards of the department of human resources of the state and standards of the city c installation of utilities after grading is completed and approved and before any base is applied to the street all of the underground work water mains gas mains etc and all service connections shall be installed completed and approved throughout the length of the road and across the flat section where the utility mains are off the pavement the developer may elect to omit the installation of service connections providing that at such time as these service connections are needed they may be jacked across the street without breaking or weakening the existing pavement d easements for utilities except where alleys are permitted for that purpose the city may require easements for poles wires conduits storm and sanitary sewers gas and water mains or other utility lines along rear lot lines or side lot lines if in the opinion of the city utilities director such action is desirable easements of the same or greater width may be required along the line of or across lots where necessary for the extension of existing or planned utilities where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse drainageway channel or stream there shall be provided a stormwater easement or drainage rightofway along each side for the purpose of widening depending relocating improving or protecting such drainage easement e street lighting either underground or overhead electrical service shall be provided by the developer of a subdivision public utility all subdivisions with underground electrical lines shall have placed appropriate utility poles for street lighting the installation of streetlights shall adhere to the following requirements streetlights shall be installed at each street intersection and streetlights that are to be installed along the proposed blocks shall be equally spaced between street intersections however the maximum distance between any two streetlights shall not exceed 400 feet in length after construction has been completed for an accepted phase or for an entire subdivision and where the streets have been dedicated to the city the city will be responsible for the costs associated with the operation of the streetlights streetlight design size and wattage must be approved by the city as part of the preliminary platting process for example a block 800 feet in length it would be necessary to install three streetlights for a block 1100 feet in length four streetlights would be necessary    monuments concrete monuments four inches in diameter or square four feet long with a flat top shall be set at all street corners at all points where the street lines intersect the exterior boundaries of the subdivision and at angle points and points of curve in each street the top of the monument shall have an indented cross to identify properly the location and shall be set flush with the finished grade all other lot corners shall be marked with iron pipe not less than threefourths inches in diameter and 24 inches long and driven so as to be flush with the finished grade    large tracts when land is subdivided into larger parcels than ordinary building lots such parcels shall be arranged so as to allow for the opening of future streets and logical further resubdivision    group housing developments a comprehensive group housing development including the large scale construction of housing units together with necessary drives and ways of access may be approved by the planning commission although the design of the project does not include standard street lot and subdivision arrangements if departure from the foregoing standards can be made without destroying their intent the developer shall provide proof that adequate access is provided for emergency vehicles    traffic and vehicles footnotes  1  state law reference traffic generally ocga  4011 et seq  power of local authorities generally ocga  406371  secs 8648624  reserved article ii  administration and enforcement division 1  generally authority of police and fire department officials a it shall be the duty of the officers of the police or other law or ordinance e marking crosswalks safety zones traffic lanes the utilities director is hereby authorized 1 to designate and maintain by appropriate devices marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway crosswalks at intersections where there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway and at such other places as such engineer may deem necessary 2 to establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as may be necessary for the protection of pedestrians 3 to make lanes for traffic on street pavements at such places as may be advisable consistent with owner liable for parking violation it shall be unlawful for any person to allow permit or suffer any vehicle registered in such persons name to stand or park in any street in violation of this chapter or any other ordinance of the city regulating the parking of vehicles such person shall be equally liable with the operator for such violation and in addition thereto may have the vehicle impounded  provided however this shall not apply in those instances described in ocga  406207    presumption in reference to illegal parking a in any prosecution charging a violation of any law or regulation governing the standing or parking of a vehicle proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked in violation of any such law or regulation together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was at the time of such parking the registered owner of such vehicle shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point where and for the time which such violation occurred  provided however this shall not apply in those instances described in ocga  406207 b the foregoing stated presumption shall apply only when the procedure in section 8649 has been followed    notice on illegally parked vehicle whenever any motor vehicle without a driver is found parked or stopped in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by this chapter or other ordinance of this city or by state law the officer finding such vehicle shall take its registration number and may take other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its user and shall conspicuously affix to such vehicle a notice in writing on a form provided by the city clerk for the driver to answer to the charge at the time and place specified in the notice    when summons for arrest to be issued in the event any person fails to comply with a notice given to such person or attached to a vehicle or fails to make appearance pursuant to a summons or if any person fails or refuses to deposit bail as required and within the time permitted by ordinance the city clerk shall forthwith secure and issue a summons for such persons arrest    when warrants for arrest to be issued when it shall be made to appear to the municipal court that any person has been lawfully served with a copy of charges to appear in such court for trial and shall fail to appear at the time and place set forth in such copy of charges it shall be the duty of the municipal judge to forthwith issue a warrant for the arrest of such person and deliver same to the chief of police    secs 86528675  reserved article iii  vehicle operation maximum speed limitsgenerally motor vehicles shall not be driven at a higher rate of speed than 30 miles per hour in the city nor a higher rate of speed than ten miles per hour in any park or cemetery owned and maintained by the city    state law reference speed limits generally ocga  406181 samein school zones it shall be unlawful for any person to drive a motor vehicle on streets adjoining school property during school days in excess of 15 miles per hour    speed zones established the following speed zones are established for vehicles upon the following streets within the corporate limits of the city as follows 1 onsystem signs to be erected by the state violation of this article each such violation shall be punishable in accordance with section 18 it is the intention of this section that each hour that any vehicle shall be parked without complying with the provisions of this article shall be a separate offense and that time is the gravamen of the offense insofar as the successive violations shall occur    parking prohibited at certain times section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning abandoned motor vehicle means a motor vehicle which has been parked or left standing on the public streets of the city for more than five days in a nonoperating state of repair abandonment means the act of the owner leaving the vehicle on the streets or sidewalks of the city for a period in excess of five days when the owner of the vehicle does not own the property abutting the street or sidewalk upon which the vehicle is parked and does not reside room have a place of business lease rent or otherwise exercise control and dominion over the abutting real estate hazard to normal flow of traffic means a vehicle parked on the public streets of the city in a nonoperational condition and is hereby defined to be a hazard to the normal flow of traffic on the streets of the city nonoperational vehicle means a vehicle that will not start run and move under its own power in its existing condition vehicle means any automobile truck trailer motorcycle wagon or other artificial contrivance used or capable of being used as a means of transportation on land    state law reference similar definitions ocga  40111 unlawful to shall be as provided in section 18 of this  20161 7192007 utilities article i  in general discontinuance of city services when charges remain unpaid any person failing for any reason or refusing to pay timely the monthly water gas sewerage or refuse collection charges provided in this by the city after having been duly billed for same by the city shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this chapter and all water service gas service sewerage service and refuse collection service provided by the city to the premises for which the monthly charges are past due shall be terminated by the city  provided however should not more than one of the monthly water charges gas charges sewerage charges and refuse collection charges remain unpaid any person may make application to the finance director to have the city services restored that are not in arrears provided such person submits a monthly repayment plan to the finance director to pay for the particular services that are in arrears within a threemonth period of time from the date of such application  and provided that the person abides by each proposed monthly payment within said threemonth time period      refunds of utility payments a in the event that a city utility customer claims that he has overpaid a utility bill or that he has been charged more than was legally due for the use of city utilities then such customer may file a claim for a refund with the finance director at any time within three years after the date of the payment of the amount for which a refund is claimed the claim for refund shall be in writing and shall be in a form and contain the information required by the finance director such claim shall include a summary statement of the grounds upon which the customer relies in claiming the refund the customer may be required to provide such additional information as may be requested by the finance director in order for the clerk to consider the claim b upon receipt of the claim and any additional information required from the customer by the finance director the finance director shall consider the claim and determine whether or not the customer is entitled to a refund but in no event shall any refund be provided for any payments made more than three years prior to the date of filing the claim for refund the finance director shall only grant the claim for refund if the finance director determines that the amount for which the refund is sought was billed to the customer erroneously or illegally c the finance director shall notify the customer of the finance directors decision regarding the refund claim within 30 days from the date that the finance director receives all information necessary in order for the finance director to make a determination regarding the refund claim d any customer whose claim for refund is denied by the finance director may appeal such denial to the city council within 30 days of the date of the finance directors decision the city council shall authorize such refund only in the event that it finds that the funds for which the refund is sought were billed to the customer either erroneously or illegally the decision of the city council regarding the claim for refund shall be final      secs 9039022  reserved article ii  backflow control footnotes  1  editors note exh a adopted nov 17 201 amended art ii in its entirety to read as
